question: How may I help you?
answer: I was hoping you could invite me inside your home and we may have a discussion.

question: Colonel Landa, this is my family. The S.S. COL clicks his heels together, and takes the hand of the French Farmers Wife...
answer: Col Hans Landa of the S.S. madame, at your service. He kisses her hand, then continues without letting go of his hostess hand... please excuse my rude intrusion on your routine. Monsieur LaPadite, the rumors I have heard in the village about your family are all true. Your wife is a beautiful woman. His eyes leave the mother, and move to the three daughters.

question: Merci. Please have a seat. The Farmer offers The S.S. Colonel a seat at the families wooden dinner table. The Nazi officer excepts the French Farmers offer, and lowers himself into the chair. Placing his grey S.S. cap on the table, and keeping his black attache case on the floor by his feet. The Farmer turns to his Wife and says; Charlotte, would you be so good as to get The Colonel some wine?
answer: Merci be coupe Monsieur LaPadite, but no wine. This being a dairy farm one would be safe in assuming you have milk? Then milk is what I prefer. Monsieur, to both your family, and your cows, I say; Bravo.

question: Merci.
answer: Please, join me at your table.

question: Very well. The French Farmer sit's at his wooden dinner table across from The Nazi. The Women remain standing. Col Landa leans forward, and says to the Farmer in a low tone of
answer: Monsieur LaPadite, what we have to discuss,' would be better discussed in private. You'll notice, I left my men outdoors- if it wouldn't offend them, could you ask your lovely ladies to step outside.

question: You are right. Charlotte, would you take the girls outside. The Colonel and I need to have a few words. The Farmers wife follows her husbands orders, and gathers her daughter's taking them outside, closing the door behind them. The Two Men are alone, at the farmers dinner table, in the Farmers humble home.
answer: Monsieur LaPadite, I regret to inform you I've exhausted the extent of my French. To continue to speak it so inadequately, would only serve to embarrass me. However, I've been lead to believe you speak English quite well?

question: Oui.
answer: Well, it just so happens, I do as well. This being your house, I ask your permission to switch to English, for the remainder of the conversation?

question: By all means. They now speak ENGLISH;
answer: Monsieur LaPadite, while I'm very familiar with you, and your family. I have no way of knowing if you are familiar with who I am. Are you aware of my existence? The Farmer answers;

question: Yes.
answer: This is good. Are you aware of the job I've been ordered to carry out in France?

question: Yes. The Colonel drinks more milk.
answer: Please tell me what you've heard?

question: I've heard, the fuhrer has put you in charge of rounding up the Jews left in France who are ether hiding, or passing for Gentile. The S.S.Colonel smiles.
answer: The Fuhrer couldn't of said it better himself.

question: But the meaning of your visit, pleasant though it is, is mysterious to me. The Germans looked through my house nine months ago for hiding Jews, and found nothing.
answer: I'm aware of that, I read the report on this area. But like any enterprise, when under new management, there's always a slight duplication of efforts. Most of it being a complete waste of time, but needs to be done nevertheless. I just have A few questions Monsieur LaPadite, if you can assist me with answers, my department can close the file on your family. Taking his black leather attache case, and placing it on the table, he takes out a folder from inside. He also extracts a expensive black fountain pen from his uniform front pocket. Opening the folder, and referring to it; Now before the occupation there were four Jewish families in this area, all dairy farmers like yourself. The Loveitts, The Doleracs, The Rollins, and The Dreyfus's, is that correct?

question: To my knowledge those were the Jewish families among the dairy farmers. - Heer Colonel, would it disturb you if I smoked my pipe? Looking up from his papers.
answer: Please, Monsieur LaPadite, it is your house, make yourself comfortable. The Farmer gets up from the table, goes to his shelf over the fireplace, and removes from it a WOODEN BOX that contains all the fixins to his pipe. He sits back down at the table with his Nazi guest. As The Farmer loads the bowel of his pipe with tobacco, sets a match to it, and begins slowly puffing, making it red hot, the S.S. Colonel studies the papers in front of him. Now according to these papers, all the Jewish families in this area have been accounted for - except, The Dreyfusis. Somewhere in the last year it would appear they have vanished. Which leads me to the conclusion that they've ether made good their escape, or someone is very successfully hiding them. (looking up from his papers, across the table at The

question: Only rumors -
answer: - I love rumors! Facts can be so misleading, where rumors, true or false are often reveling. So Monsieur LaPadite, what rumors have you heard regarding The Dreyfusis? The Farmerlooks at Landa. Speak freely Monsieur LaPadite, I want to hear what the rumors are, not who told them to you. The Farmer puffs thoughtfully on his pipe.

question: Again, this is just a rumor - but we heard the Dreyfusis had made there way into Spain.
answer: So the rumors you've heard have been of escape?

question: Yes.
answer: Were the LaPadites and the Dreyfusis friendly? As the Farmer answers this question, the CAMERA LOWERS behind his chair, to the floor, past the floor, to a small area underneath the floorboards revealing;

question: We were families in the same community, in the same bussiness. I wouldn't say we were friends, but members of the same community, we had common interest. The S.S. Colonel takes in this answer, seems to except it, then moves to the next question.
answer: Having never met the Dreyfusis, would you confirm for me the exact members of the household and their names?

question: There were five of them. The father, Jacob... .wife, Miram... her brother, Bob ...
answer: - How old is Bob?

question: Thirty - thirty one?
answer: Continue.

question: And the children... Amos... and Shoshanna.
answer: Ages of the children?

question: Amos - six - I believe. And Shosanna, was fifteen or sixteen, I'm not really sure.
answer: Well I guess that should do it. Be begins gathering up his papers, and putting them back into his ttache case. the Farmer, cool as a cucumber, puffs on his pipe. However, before I go, could I have another glass of your delicious milk?

question: But of course. Farmer stands up, goes over to the ice box, and takes out the aft of milk. As he walks over and fills the Nazi Colonel's glass, German Officer talks.
answer: Monsieur LaPadite, are you aware of the nickname the people of France have given me?

question: I have no interest in such things.
answer: But you are aware of what they call me?

question: I'm aware.
answer: What are you aware of?

question: That they call you, "The Jew Hunter".
answer: Precisely! Now I understand your trepidation in repeating it. Before he was assassinated, Heydrich apparently hated the moniker the good people of Prague bestowed on him. Actually why he would hate the name, "The Hangman", is baffling to me It would appear he did everything in his power to earn it. But I, on the other hand, love my unofficial title, precisely because I've earned it. As "The Jew Hunter" enjoys his fresh milk, he continues to theorize with the french farmer. The feature that makes me such a effective hunter of the Jews, is, as opposed to most German soldiers, I can think like a jew. where they can only think like a German, or more precisely, a German soldier. Now if one were to determine what attribute the German people share with a beast, it would be the cunning and predatory instinct of a hawk.

question: I suppose I would.
answer: Has a rat ever done anything to you to create this animosity you feel toward them?

question: Rat's spread disease, they bite people -
answer: - Unless some fool is stupid enough to try and handle a live one, rats don't make it a practise of biting human beings. Rats were the cause of the bubonic plague, but that was some time ago. In all your born days, has a rat ever caused you to be sick a day in your life? I purpose to you, any disease a rat could spread, a squirrel could equally carry. Yet I assume you don't share the same animosity with squirrels that you do with rats, do you?

question: No.
answer: Yet, they are both rodent's, are they not? And except for the fact that one has a big bushy tail, while the other has a long repugnt tail of rodent skin, they even rather look alike, don't they?

question: It is a interesting thought, beer Colonel.
answer: However, interesting as the thought may be, it makes not one bit of difference to how you feel. If a rat were to scamper through your door, this very minute, would you offer it a saucer of your delicious milk?

question: Probably not.
answer: I didn't think so. You don't like them. You don't really know why you don't like them. All you know is, you find them repulsive. (let's the

question: Please, Cononel, make yourself at home.
answer: The other mistake the German soldier make is their severe handling of the citizens who give shelter and aid to the Jews. These citizens are not enemies of the state. They are simply confused people, trying to make some sense out of the madness war creates. These citizens do not need punishing. They simply need to be reminded of their duty in war time. Let's use you as a example Monsieur LaPadite. In this war, you have found yourself in the middle of a conflict that has nothing to do with yourself, your lovely ladies, or your cows - yet, here you are. So Monsieur LaPadite, let me purpose a question. In this time of war, what is your number one duty? Is it to fight the Germans in the name of France to your last breath? Or, is it to harass the occupying army to the best of your ability? Or, is it to protect the poor unfortunate victims of warfare who can not protect themselfs? Or, is your number one duty in this time of bloodshed, to protect those very beautiful women who constitute your family? The Colonel lets the last statement stand. That was a question Monsieur LaPadite. In this time of war, What do you consider your number one duty?

question: To protect my family.
answer: Now, my job dictates, that I must have my men enter your home, and conduct a thorough search, before I can officially cross your families name off my list. You are sheltering enemies of the state, are you not?

question: Yes.
answer: Your sheltering them underneath your floorboards aren't you?

question: Yes.
answer: Point out to me the area's where their hiding. The Farmer points out the area's on the floor with the Dreyfusis are underneath. Since I haven't heard any disturbance, I assume that while their listening, they don't speak english?

question: Yes .
answer: I'm going to switch back to french now, and I want you to follow my masquerade - is that clear?

question: Yes. Colonel Landa stands up from the table, and switching to FRENCH says
answer: Monsieur LaPadite, I thank you for milk, and your hospitably. I do believe our business here is done. The Nazi Officer opens the front door, and silently motions for his son to approach the house. Mademoiselle LaPadite, I thank you for your time, we shant be bothering your family any longer. Yet the LaPadite women watch the Nazi soldiers, machine guns at ready, approach the house. The Soldiers enter the doorway, Col Landa, silently points out area of the floor the Jews are hiding under. So, Monsieur and Madame LaPadite I bid you adieu. otions to the Soldiers with his index finger. wy TEAR UP the wood floor with MACHINE GUN FIRE. The little farm house is filled with SMOKE, DUST, SPLINTERS, SCREAMS, 0ULLET CASINGS, and even alittle BLOOD. With a hand motion from the Colonel, the Soldiers cut off their gunfire. The Colonel keeps his finger in the air to indicate silence. It's the girl. Nobody moves ae he crosses the floor, he see's the young girl RUNNING towards the cover of the woods. He unlatches the window, and opens it. Shosanna to perfectly FRAMED in the window sill. Pramed by the window, takes his LUGAR, and straight arm aims at the fleeing Jew, cocking back the hammer with his thumb. Au revoir, Shosanna! Till we meet again! Herman, I sense` a question on your lips? Out with it?

question: Monsieur LaPadite, I thank you for milk, and your hospitably. I do believe our business here is done. The Nazi Officer opens the front door, and silently motions for his son to approach the house. Mademoiselle LaPadite, I thank you for your time, we shant be bothering your family any longer. Yet the LaPadite women watch the Nazi soldiers, machine guns at ready, approach the house. The Soldiers enter the doorway, Col Landa, silently points out area of the floor the Jews are hiding under. So, Monsieur and Madame LaPadite I bid you adieu. otions to the Soldiers with his index finger. wy TEAR UP the wood floor with MACHINE GUN FIRE. The little farm house is filled with SMOKE, DUST, SPLINTERS, SCREAMS, 0ULLET CASINGS, and even alittle BLOOD. With a hand motion from the Colonel, the Soldiers cut off their gunfire. The Colonel keeps his finger in the air to indicate silence. It's the girl. Nobody moves ae he crosses the floor, he see's the young girl RUNNING towards the cover of the woods. He unlatches the window, and opens it. Shosanna to perfectly FRAMED in the window sill. Pramed by the window, takes his LUGAR, and straight arm aims at the fleeing Jew, cocking back the hammer with his thumb. Au revoir, Shosanna! Till we meet again! Herman, I sense` a question on your lips? Out with it?
answer: Why did yoy allow a enemy of the state to escape?

question: Oh, I don't think the state is in too much danger, do you?
answer: I suppose not.

question: Up the road a piece, there's a orchard. 'sides you, we know there's another kraut patrol fuckin around here somewhere. Now if that patrol were to have any crackshots, that orchard, would be a goddamn snipers delight. Now if you ever wanna eat a sauerkraut sandwich again, you gotta show me on this map, where they are, you gotta tell me how many they are, and you gotta tell me, what kinda artillery they carrying with 'em?
answer: You can't expect me to divulge information that would put German lives in danger?

question: well, Werner that's where your wrong. Because that's exactly what I expect. I need to know about Germans hidin in trees? And you need to tell me? And you need to tell me, right now? Now take your finger, and point out on this map, where this partys bein held, how manys comin, and what they brought to play with? Werner site, head held high, back straight, chin up, every inch the German hero facing death. You see that ole boy battin rocks? WE RACK FOCUS to a one of The Basterds not in the circle. He's wearing a wife beater, and power hitting stones with a baseball bat. Werners eyes go to the ballplayer. That's Sgt.Donny Donowitz. But you might know him better by his nickname, The Bear Jew. Now if you heard of Aldo the Apache, you gotta heard about The Bear Jew?
answer: I heard.

question: What did you hear?
answer: He beats German soldiers with a club.

question: .ya got the goddamn fuckin Germans, declaring open season on Jews in Europe, and I'm suppose to fly to the fuckin Philippines, and fight a bunch of fuckin Japs - not me pal. If we just go in this against the Japs, the whole U.S.of fuckin A can go take a running jump at the moon. Hey, stick your treason up your poop hole. If I'm gonna kill my fellow man in the name of liberty, that fellow man, will be German.
answer: Hello Donny, how are you?

question: Ah, just dandy, Mr.Goorowitz.
answer: Your mother, your father - everything good there?

question: There just fine. I'm shippin off next week. The store proprietor, extends his hand to the young man.
answer: Good for you son. Kill one of those Nazi basterds for me, will ya?

question: That's the idea, Mr.Goorowitz.
answer: What can I do you for, Donny?

question: I need a baseball bat. The store owner leads him to a basket with eight bats init. Donny starts going through them without saying anything.
answer: You gettin your little brother a present before you ship out? Donny, concentrating on the bats, not looking up;

question: No. Donny's "no", silences the gabby Goorowitz. He seems to settle on one, feeling it's weight in his hands. Can I try this one on for size, outside?
answer: Be my guest. The phone rings. I'll get that, you go right ahead. The proprietor answers the phone, and gets into a conversation with his OFF SCREEN Mother. Donny walks outside, WE STAY IN STORE, but can see him clearly through the stores big picture window. However, Mr.Goorowitz instinctively, turns his back to Donny to speak with his mother. Donny starts swinging the bat. It's pretty obvious he's pantomiming beating somebody to death with it. Then the he starts yelling;

question: Take that ya Nazi basterd! You like fuckin with the Jews? Wanna Fuck with the Jews? The American jews are gonna FUCK with you... ..! Mr.Goorowitz, see's none of this, as he speaks to his mother. He hangs up the phone, just as Donny walks back into the store. Store owner turns to store customer. Is this the heaviest ya got? Mrs.Himmelstein?
answer: State your business young man.

question: Mrs.Himmelstein, I'm Donny Donowitz, my father Sy Donowitz, owns the barber shop on Greeny Ave, "Sy's Barber Shop".
answer: I've seen it. Do you live in the neighbourhood?

question: All my life.
answer: Again, state your business?

question: May I have a word with you?
answer: What about?

question: Our people in Europe. She thinks for a beat, then holds the door open for the young man.
answer: Come in. Would you like some tea?

question: Very good.
answer: If you like tea. Donny chuckles at her little joke. The old woman remains stone. She wasn't joking. He places his saucer on the coffee table and begins;

question: Mrs.Himmelstein, do you have any love ones over in Europe who your concerned for?
answer: What compels you young man, to ask a stranger such a personal question?

question: Because I'm going to Europe. And I'm gonna make it right.
answer: And just how do intend to do that, Joshua? And what exactly do you intend to do with that toy?

question: I'm gonna beat every Nazi I find to death with it.
answer: I thought we were having tea together? And in this pursuit, how is it that I can be of service?

question: You must be a real BASTERD, Donny?
answer: You bet your sweet ass I am.

question: Good. A Basterds work is never done. Specially in Germany. Donny steps up to the plate, looking down at the Nazi;
answer: Gimmie your papers. Werner hands Donny up his papers. Donny RIPS the identity page out, and sticks it in his pocket.

question: watches. Hirschberg says to him;
answer: You wanna live?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Point out on this map, the German position. His arm shoots out like a rocket, and points out the positions.

question: This area here.
answer: How many?

question: Maybe twelve.
answer: What kinda of artillery?

question: You are not to tell anybody anything! Not one word of detail! Your outfit was ambushed, and you got a away. Not one word more.
answer: Yes mine Fuhrer.

question: Did they mark you like they did the other survivors?
answer: Yes mine Fuhrer.

question: So young woman, since it's beyond obvious we're closed for the evening. I must assume you want something. What can I do for you?
answer: May I sleep here tonight?

question: So I gather your not a nurse?
answer: No.

question: But your a bright little thing, that's clever disguise. Where is your family?
answer: Murdered.

question: So your a war orphan?
answer: We were from Nancy. The Bosch found us

question: Is this a sad story?
answer: Oui.

question: Sad stories bore me. These days everyone in Paris has one. I haven't bore you with mine, don't bore me with yours.
answer: You can run the machines?

question: What machines? Using her hands to pantomime the rotating film reels on a projector, she says;
answer: The machines that show the film?

question: The projectors? Yes, I own a cinema, of course I can operate them.
answer: I know, I saw you.

question: expertly working the projectors...
answer: Teach me. Teach me to run the machines, that show the film. It's only you and the negro. I know you could use some help.

question: I know at least six people who've been put up against a wall, and machine gunned for sheltering enemies of the state. I have no intention of being unlucky number seven. How long have you been in Paris?
answer: A week, and a few days.

question: How have you survived the curfew without capture?
answer: I sleep on rooftops.

question: Again, I'm forced to admit, clever girl. How is it?
answer: Cold. Respectfully, no you can't.

question: Fair enough. So you can't operate a 35mm film projector, you want me teach you, in order to work here, in order to use my cinema, as a hole to hide in, is that correct?
answer: Oui.

question: Whats your name?
answer: Shosanna.

question: I'm Madame Mimieux. You may call me Madame. This is a cinema. Not a home for wayward war orphans. Having said that, what you say is true. If you were truly exceptional, I could find use for you. So Shosanna, are you truly exceptional?
answer: Oui Madame.

question: I will be the judge of that.
answer: THROWS the lever on the 2nd PROJECTOR, switching the film from projector 1# to projector 2#, executing a perfect REEL CHANGE. As Shosanna's Theme plays on the Soundtrack, we watch viva MONTAGE, her go through her daily chores. Carry heavy film cans up the stairs, empty the rat traps, ect,ect...

question: What starts tomorrow? Shosanna looks down, seeing the young German Solder smiling up at her from below.
answer: A Max Linder festival.

question: Ummmm, I always preferred Linder to Chaplin. Except Linder never made a film as good as "The Rid". The chase climax of "The Kid", superb. Shosanna continues working, not adding to the conversation. I suppose now you could use a "M" a "A" and a "X"?
answer: No need, I can manage.

question: Don't be ridiculous, it's my pleasure. He hands the French damsel the letters spelling MAX.
answer: Merci.

question: I adore your cinema very much.
answer: Merci. She busies herself with the marquee letters...

question: How does a young girl, such as yourself, own a cinema? Do to his uniform, and Shosanna's situation, all his efforts at trying to make small talk, strikes the young Jewess in hiding as a Gestapo interrogation.
answer: My aunt left it to me.

question: Lucky girl. Shosanna makes no reply back. Merci for hoisting a German night.
answer: I don't have a choice, but your welcome.

question: Do you chose the German films yourself?
answer: Oui.

question: Then my merci stands. I love the Refensthal mountain films, especially, "Pizu Palu". It's nice to see a French girl who's a admirer of Refensthal.
answer: "Admire", would not be the adjective I would use to describe my feelings towards Fraulein Refensthal.

question: But you do admire the director. Pabst, don't you? That's why you included his name on the marquee. She climbs down from the ladder and faces the German Private.
answer: I'm French. We respect directors in our country.

question: Apparently even Germans.
answer: Even Germans. Merci for assistance, Private. Adieu. She turns to go back inside.

question: Your not finished?
answer: I'll finish in the morning. She opens the door to go inside.

question: May I ask your name?
answer: You wish to see my papers? She hands him her excellently forged papers. That's obviously not what he meant, but he takes them anyway to read her name.

question: Emmanuelle Mimieux. That's a very pretty name.
answer: Merci. Are you finished with my papers? He hands them back.

question: if I ever see you light up a cigarette in my cinema again, I'll turn you into the Nazi's, do you understand? Shosanna is shocked by this statement.
answer: Oui, Madame.

question: And for bringing a open flame in my cinema, you deserve far worse then a Nazi jewish boxcar. With your thick head, what do you think the highest priority of a cinema manager is? Keeping this fucking place from burning down to the ground, that's what! In my collection, I have over 350, 35mm, nitrate film prints, which are not only immensely flammable, but highly unstable. And should they catch fire, they burn three times faster then paper. If that happens.. .POOF...all gone, cinema no more, every body burned alive. If I ever see you with a open flame in my cinema again, I won't turn you into the Nazi's I'll kill you myself. And the fucking Germans will give me a curfew pass. Do you understand me?
answer: Out, Madame.

question: Do you believe me?
answer: Out, Madame.

question: I know. I'm fine, darling. I'll be to bed soon. Marcel goes back inside, Shosanna smokes.
answer: May I join you?

question: Look Fredrick - Yes....Look, you seem a pleasant enough fellow -
answer: - Merci.

question: Your welcome. - regardless, I want you to stop pestering me.
answer: I apologize mademoiselle, I wasn't trying to be a pest. I was simply trying to be friendly.

question: I don't wish to be your friend.
answer: Why not?

question: Don't act like a infant. You know why.
answer: I'm more then just a uniform.

question: Not to me. If you are so desperate for a French girlfriend, I suggest you try Vichy? Just then TWO OTHER GERMAN SOLDIERS come over, obviously very impressed with Fredrick. They make a fuss over him in UNSUBTITLED GERMAN, which nether Shosanna, or the non German speaking members of the movies audience, can understand. He signs autographs for them, shakes their hands, and they go on their way. Shosanna's eyes narrow. Who are you?
answer: I thought I was just a uniform?

question: Your not just a German soldier, are you somebodies son?
answer: Most German soldiers are somebodies son.

question: Yeah, but your not just somebody. What are you, Hitlers nephew? He leans in across the table, she leans in too, and he says;
answer: Yes.

question: Really?
answer: No not really, I'm just teasing you. She leans back annoyed.

question: Then what is it? What are you, a German movie star?
answer: Not exactly.

question: , what does that mean, "not exactly". I asked if you were a movie star, the answer to that question, is yes or no. Fredrick laughs at that line. You were raised by Helga?
answer: All my sisters, I'm the baby, but Helga was the bossiest.

question: And your mother and father?
answer: My mother died. And my father was a loser. My fathers moto; "If at first you don't succeed, quit". The day he left, good riddance. My sisters are all I need. It's why I like your cinema. It makes me feel both closer to them, and a little homesick at the same time.

question: is your cinema still operatiing? What's it called?
answer: The Kino Haus.

question: How has it done durring the war?
answer: Actually, in Germany, cinema attendance is up.

question: No doubt, you don't have to operate under a curfew.
answer: How often do you fill your house?

question: , not since before the war.
answer: So if you had one big engagement, that would help you out?

question: Of course, but that's not likely to happen. TWO MORE GERMAN SOLDIERS and their TWO FRENCH DATES approach the table. They ask for Fredricks autograph, he signs it for them. One of the French Girls says in FRENCH, how exciting it is to meet a real live German war hero. Shosanna hears it. They leave. So that's it, she thinks. So your a war hero? Why didn't you tell me?
answer: Everybody knows that, I liked you didn't.

question: What did you do? He takes a sip of beer.
answer: I've shot the most enemy soldiers in world war two...so far. You bet your sweet ass that got her attention.

question: Wow.
answer: I was alone in a bell tower in a walled off city in Russia. It was myself, and a thousand rounds of ammo, in a bird's nest, against three hundred Soviet soldiers.

question: What's a bird's nest?
answer: A bird's nest is what a sniper would call a bell tower. It's a high structure, offering a three hundred and sixty degree view. Very advantageous for marksmen.

question: How many Russian's did you kill?
answer: Sixty-eight.

question: Maybe they'll make a film about your exploits.
answer: Well, that's just what Joseph Goebbels thought. So he did. It's called "Nation's Pride", and guess what, they wanted me to play myself, so I did. They have posters for it in kiosks all over Paris. That's another reason for all the attention.

question: "Nation's Pride" is about you? "Nation's Pride" is starring you?
answer: I know, comical, huh?

question: Not so comical. So what are you doing in Paris, enjoying a rest?
answer: Hardly. I've been doing publicity, having my picture taken with different German luminaries, visiting troops, that sort of thing. Goebbels wants the film to premier in Paris, so I've been helping them in the planning. Joseph is very keen on this film. He's telling anybody who will listen, when "Nation's Pride" is released, I'll be the German Van Johnson. Shosanna, wasn't falling for the young German, by any stretch. However his exploits, as well as his charming manner, can't help but impress. But his referring to Goebbels as "Joseph", like their friends, is all she needed to get on the right side of things. This young man is trouble with a capital "T", and she needs to stay far fucking away from him. She abruptly rises, and says;

question: I see your public speaking has improved. It appears I've created a monster. A strangely persuasive monster. When the war's over, politics awaits. Table chuckles. Well Private, though it is true, I'm inclined to indulge you anything. I must watch a film in this young ladies cinema before I can say, yes or no. So young lady, you are to close your cinema tonight, and have a private screening me. Francesca interprets... What German films do you have? Francesca asks..
answer: My cinema , on German night, tends to show older German classics. Francesca interprets...

question: Why not my films? Francesca asks...
answer: I draw a older German audience in my cinema, that appreciate the nostalgia of the earlier time. Francesca interprets...

question: That's nonsense fraulein. Us Germans are looking forward, not backwards. That era of German cinema is dead. The German cinema I create, will not only be thee cinema of Europe. But the worlds only alternative to the degenerate Jewish influence of Hollywood. Fredrick Jumps in...
answer: Along with being a cinema owner, Emmanuelle is quite a formidable film critic. He chuckles, but alone.

question: WSo it would appear. Unfortunately for the fraulein, I've outlawed film criticism. Zoller, thinking fast, says;
answer: Why don't you screen "Lucky Kids"? I'm sure Emmanuelle hasn't seen. it. And it's so funny, I've been meaning to recommend it to her, for her German night. That's a great idea, let's watch "Lucky Kids" tonight.

question: Ahhh, "Lucky Kids", "Lucky Kids", "Lucky Kids". When all is said and done, my most purely enjoyable production. Not only that, I wouldn't be surprised, if sixty years from now, It's "Lucky Kids" that I'm the most remembered for. I know it doesn't seem like it now, but mark my words. Very well, I'll have a print sent over to the fraulein'.s cinema. We'll screen "Lucky Kids" tonight. Ah Landa, your here, this is the young lady in question. The S.S. Officer sits down, and it's our old friend from the first scene COL HANS LANDA.
answer: Shosanna, this4pol Hans Landa of the SS., he'll be running security for the premier.

question: Oh Francesca, what was that funny thing the Fuhrer said about Hans?
answer: What thing?

question: You know, you were there, it was a funny thing the Fuhrer said, about Hans...Something about a pig? Francesca's memory is jogged.
answer: Oh, yes of course. She repeats it by whispering it in Goebbels ear.

question: Oh, yes of course, that's it. So the Fuhrer said, he wouldn't be surprised if Hans weren't rooting out Jews like a truffle pig from the play pen.
answer: That's what we need, pigs that can root out Jews.

question: Who needs pigs when you have me? Big hearty laugh around the table.
answer: Do you have a engagement tonight?

question: Well, as a matter of fact, I do -
answer: - Break it. We're all going to the Fraulein's cinema tonight to view "Lucky Kids".

question: Have you tried the strudel here?
answer: No.

question: It's not so terrible. So how is it the young Private and yourself came to be acquainted? She's about to answer, when a WAITER approaches. Yes, two strudels, one for myself, and one for the mademoiselle. A cup of espresso, with a container of. steamed milk, on the side. For the Mademoiselle, a glass of milk. Considering Shosanna. grew up on a dairy farm, and the last time she was on a dairy farm, her strudel companion murdered her entire family, his ordering her milk is, to say the least... . disconcerting. The key to Col Landa's power, and or charm, depending on the side ones on, lies in his ability to convince you he's privy to your secrets. So Mademoiselle, you were beginning to explain....? - Mademoiselle, let me interrupt you. This is a simple formality, no reason for you to feel anxious. The Colonel takes one look at it, and says to the Waiter; I apologize, I forgot to order the cream fresh. Wait for the cream. (Back to
answer: Oui.

question: So Emmanuelle, explain to me how does it happen, that a young lady such as your self, comes to own a cinema? The Waiter returns, applying cream fresh to the two strudels. The S.S. Colonel looks across the table at his companion, picking up his fork, he says; After you. Shosanna takes a whip creamy bite of strudel, Landa follows her lead.
answer: The cinema originally belonged to my aunt and uncle - Col Landa removes alittle black book from his pocket.

question: - What is there names?
answer: Jean-Pierre and Ada Mimieux. He records the names in his little book.

question: Where are they now?
answer: My uncle was killed during blitzkrieg.

question: Pity... . Continue.
answer: Aunt Ada passed away from fever last spring.'

question: Regrettable.
answer: Yes, he's a Frenchman. His name is Marcel. He worked with my aunt and uncle since they opened the cinema. He's the only other one who works with me.

question: Doing what?
answer: Projectionist.

question: Is he any good?
answer: The best.

question: Actually one could see where that might be a good trade for them. Can you operate the projectors?
answer: Of course I can.

question: Knowing the Reich Minister as I do, I'm quite positive he wouldn't want the success or failure of his illustrious evening, dependent on the prowess of a negro. So if it comes to pass we hold this event at your venue, talented no doubt, as your negro may be, you will operate the projectors. Is that exceptable? As if she has any say.
answer: Oui. Col Landa takes another bite of strudel, Shosanna follows suit.

question: So it would appear our young hero is quite smitten with you?
answer: Private Zollers feelings for me aren't of a romantic nature.

question: Mademoiselle...?
answer: Colonel, his feelings are not romantic. I remind him of his sister.

question: That doesn't mean his feelings aren't romantic.
answer: I remind him of his sister who raised him.

question: It's sounding more and more romantic by the minute. Landa takes out a handsome looking cigarette case, with a S.S. LOGO on it. Removing on of the fags, he lights it up with a fancy S.S. gold lighter. He offers one to Shosanna. Cigarette?
answer: No thank you.

question: Do you smoke?
answer: Yes.

question: What the fuck are we suppose to do?
answer: It looks like we're suppose to have a Nazi premier.

question: Like I said, what the fuck are we suppose to do?
answer: Well, I need to speak with you about that.

question: About what?
answer: About these Hun swine, commandeering our cinema.

question: What about it? She slowly walks up the stairs to Marcel. She makes him part his legs, and sits on the lower step, between his legs. Her back up against his chest, his arms around her shoulders. Shosanna has only known this type of intimacy with Marcel.
answer: Well, when I was watching the bosch (Said in

question: I'm confused, what are we talking about?
answer: Filling the cinema with Nazi's and their whores, and burning it down to the ground.

question: I'm not talking about that, your talking about that.
answer: No, we're talking about that, right now. If we can keep this place from burning down by ourselves, we can burn it down by ourselves.

question: Shosanna -
answer: No, Marcel, just for sake of argument, if we wanted to burn down the cinema, for any number of reasons, you and I could physically accomplish that, no?

question: Oui Shosanna, we could do that.
answer: And with Madame Mimieux's 350 nitrate film print collection, we wouldn't even need explosives, would we?

question: You mean we wouldn't need any more explosives?
answer: Oui, that's exactly what I mean. She begins kissing his hands.

question: Quite well, actually. I recorded a new guitarist I met in a cafe last week. It works superb. Why do we need filmmaking equipment?
answer: Because Marcel, my sweet, we're going to make a film. Just for the Nazi's.

question: if you offered me a scotch and plane water, I could drink a scotch and plain water.
answer: That a boy, Lieutenant. Make it yourself, like a good chap, will you? Bars in the globe. Hicox heads over to the bar globe.

question: Something for yourself, sir?
answer: Whiskey straight. No junk in it. The Lieutenant moves over to the Columbus-style globe bar, and busies himself mixing spirits, playing bartender chappy. Fenech, eyeing the Lieutenant's file. It says here you've run three undercover commando operations in Germany, and German occupied territories? Frankfaurt, Holland, and Norway to be exact? Back to them, mixing drinks, he says;

question: Extraordinary people, the Norwegian's.
answer: It says here you speak German fluently?

question: Like a Katzenjammer Kid.
answer: And your occupation before the war? His back still to us, as he bartends... List your accomplishments?

question: Well sir, such as they are, I write reviews and articles, for a publication called; "Films and Filmmakers". As well as our sister publication.
answer: What's that called?

question: "Flickers Bi-Monthly". And I've had two books published.
answer: Impressive. Don't be modest Lieutenant, what are their titles?

question: "Twenty-Four Frame Da Vinci". It's a subtexual film criticism study of the work of German director G.W. Pabst.
answer: Down with Hitler.

question: All the way down, sir.
answer: Are you familiar with German cinema under the Third Reich? Explain it to me.?

question: Pardon sir?
answer: This little escapade of ours, requires a knowledge of the German film industry under the Third Reich. Explain to me UFA, under Goebbels?

question: Goebbels considers the films he's making to be the beginning of a new era in German cinema. A alternative to what he considers the Jewish German intellectual cinema of the twenties. And the Jewish controlled dogma of Hollywood. SUDDENLY... Bellowing from the back of the room; Quite well, actually. Since Goebbels has taken over, film attendance has steadily risen in Germany over the last eight years. But Louis B.Mayer wouldn't be Goebbels proper opposite number. I believe Goebbels see's himself closer to David O.Selznick. Gen.Fenech looks to the Prime Minister. With a puff of cigar smoke, Churchell says; - What film sir? The General has to resort to peeking at his file.
answer: The motion pictures called; "Nation's Pride".

question: Oh, you mean the film about Private Zoller?
answer: We don't have any intelligence, on exactly, what the film that night will be about.

question: But it's called "Nation's Pride"?
answer: Yes.

question: I can tell you what it's about, it's about Private Fredrick Zoller. He's the German Sgt.York. Fenech can't help suppress a smile, they have the right man.
answer: In attendance at this joyous Germatic occasion, will be Goebbels, Gerring, Boorman, and most of the German High command, including all high ranking officers of both The S.S., and, The Gestapo. As well as luminaries of the Nazi propaganda film industry.

question: The master race at play, aye?
answer: Basically, we have all our rotten eggs in one basket. The objective of Operation Kino.... Blow up the basket.

question: "...and like the snows of yesteryear, gone from this earth". Jolly good, sir.
answer: An American Secret Service outfit, that lives deep behind enemy lines, will be your assist. The Germans call them; "The Basterds".

question: "The Basterds", never heard of them.
answer: Whole point of the secret service, old boy, you not hearing of them. But the Gerrys have heard of them, because these yanks have been them the devil. Their leader is a chap named Lt.Aldo Raine. The Germans call him, "Aldo the Apache".

question: Why do they call him that?
answer: Best guess, is because he removes the scalps of the Nazi dead.

question: Scalps, sir?
answer: The hair. He runs his finger along his hairline. Like a red Injun.

question: Rather gruesome sounding little Dicky bird, isn't he?
answer: No doubt the whole lot, a bunch a nutters. But you've heard the expression, "It takes a thief".

question: Indeed. General Fenech continues on with his exposition, moving over to a military map.
answer: You'll be dropped into France, about twenty four kilometers outside of Paris. The Basterds will be waiting for you. First thing, you go to a little village called, "Nadine". Apparently the Gerrys never go there. In Nadine, there's a tavern, called, "La Louisiane", you'll rendez-vous with our double agent, and she'll take it from there. She's the one who's going to get you in the premiere. It will be you, her, and two German born members of the Basterds. She's also made all the other arrangements your going to need.

question: How will I know her?
answer: I suspect that won't be too much trouble for you. Your contact is Bridget Von Hammersmark.

question: Bridget Von Hammersmark? The German movie star is working for England?
answer: For the last two years now. one could even say Operation Kino was her brainchild. In the back of the room the bulldog barks; You'll go to the premiere as her escort, lucky devil. She'll also have the premiere tickets for the other two. Got the gist?

question: We need a sync mark.
answer: What is a sync mark?

question: A action and noise put together, So we can sync up the picture and sound.
answer: How do we do that?

question: Clap your hands. She does. In frame imbecile. She claps her hands in front of her face. Ready? Shosanna takes a deep breath, then;
answer: Ready.

question: Action. But how do we get it developed? Only a suicidal idiot like us would develop that footage. How do we get a35mm print with a soundtrack?
answer: Do you know one person who can do both things?

question: Of course Gaspar, very nice man, took care of all the experimental filmmakers. But nobody in their right mind would strike a print of what your talking about. If the Nazi's found out, their life wouldn't be worth this. He snaps his fingers.
answer: In a wolf fight, you ether eat the wolf, or the wolf eats you. If we're going to obliterate the Nazi's, we have to use their tactics.

question: What does that mean?
answer: We find somebody who can develop and process a35mm print. And we make them do it, or we kill them. Once we tell them what we want to do, if they refuse, we have to kill them anyway, or they'll turn us in.

question: Would you do that?
answer: Like that. Snaps her fingers. Bring that fucker over here! Put his head down on that table. Marcel, holds his arm behind him, as he forces his head flat against the table top. Shosanna brings a HATCHET DOWN DEEP into the table, just by his face. You ether do what the fuck we tell you to, or I'll bury this axe in your collaborating skull. Then prove it! Or does your manhood go no deeper, then standing to piss? Marcel, does his wife, and children know you?

question: Oui.
answer: Then after we kill this dog for Germans, we'll go and silence them. She lifts up the hatchet, raises it high... Prepare to die, collaborator fucker!

question: You didn't say the goddamn rendez-vous was in a fuckin basement.
answer: I didn't know.

question: You said it was in a tavern?
answer: it is a tavern.

question: We wait. Don't worry, she's a British spy, she'll make the rendez-vous. WE SEE the other Basterds, dressed in French civilian clothes, are in the room as well, they are, Donowitz, Hirschberg, and Utivich. And in the back of the room, dressed in the grey uniform of a S.S. Lieutenant, Hugo Stiglitz sits off by himself, sharpening his S.S. DAGGER on his leather belt looped around his boot. Anybody not in the scene from the Basterds opening chapter, is dead. Lt.Hicox watches Stiglitz off by himself on the other side of the room, SHARPENS his dagger menacingly. .Stiglitz is fucking werid... Lt.Hicox approaches Stiglitz...
answer: That's right, sir. He continues bringing the blades edge, up, then, down on the leather strap.

question: I hear your pretty good with that? Meaning the blade. Stiglitz doesn't answer. You know, we're not looking for trouble, right now. We're simply making contact with our agent. Should be uneventful. However, on the off chance I'm wrong, and things prove eventful. I need to know, we can all remain calm.
answer: I don't look calm to you?

question: Well, now you put it like that, I guess you do. He turns his attention back to his blade. Hicox moves over to Aldo, and asks him privately;
answer: Is that the kinds man you need, the loquacious type?

question: Fair point, Lieutenant.
answer: So y'all git in trouble in there, what are we suppose to do? Make bets on how it all comes out?

question: If we get into trouble, we can handle it. But if trouble does happen, we need you to make damn sure no Germans, or French, for matter, escape from that basement. If Frau Von Hammersmark's cover is compromised, the mission is kaput.
answer: Speaking of Frau Von Hammersmark, who's idea was it for the death trap redez-vous?

question: She chose the spot.
answer: Well isn't that just dandy?

question: Gengus Khaun! I would never of gotten that. She walks over, and joins the masquerading Germans table, the Gentlemen rise. She greets each warmly with a french cheek kiss, as if she knows them well. They all take a seat. The two Basterds, and one Brit, drink Whiskey. The taverns PROPRIETOR, a older, big bellyed Frenchman named EARL, comes over to the table, and pours more champagne into Bridget's Champagne glass. He leaves, returning back behind the bar, with the YOUNG FRENCH BARMAID, the only other person in the establishment. Obviously, they speak GERMAN, SUBTITLED into ENGLISH;
answer: I thought this place was suppose to have more French then Germans?

question: Normally that's true. The Sgt over there's wife, just had a baby. His commanding officer gave him, and his mates the night off to celebrate. F No, we should stay. For one drink at least. I've been waiting for you in a bar, it would look strange if we left before we had a drink.
answer: She's right, just be calm, and enjoy your booze.

question: There's been some new developments. The cinema venue has changed.
answer: Why?

question: .the films gone through many delays, and Leni's heath is deteriorating, so if you have to speak... Hicox, seeing the German Master Sgt approach, signals for her to cool it.
answer: Frau Von Hammersmark, I was just thinking, could you sign a autograph to my son on his birthday?

question: I'd love to Wilhelm. This handsome happy Sgt, just became a father today. The Pretend Officers offer congratulations to the Sgt. The German Master Sgt, CLICKS his heels, and bows before his superior officers.
answer: Thank you, heil Hitler. He raises his hand .... as do the seated phony officers; "Heil Hitler". As she takes a rather fancy fountain pen from her clutch..

question: So Wilhelm, do you know the name of this progeny yet?
answer: I most certainly do, fraulein. His name is Maximilian. Even the slightly psychotic Stiglitz, likes this German Sgt.

question: T wasn't speaking to you Lt.Saltzberg, (Turning to
answer: I was born in the village that rests in the shadow of Piz Palu.

question: The mountain?
answer: Yes. In that village we all speak like this. Have you seen the Riefenstahl film?

question: Yes. Yes I do.
answer: In that scene was myself, my father, my sister, and my two brothers. My brother is so handsome, the director Pabst, gave him a Close Up. As Bridget Von Hammersmark places a cigarette in a ivory cigarette holder, which Hicox, as if on cue, lights for her, she says;

question: So that's the source of your bazaar accent? Extraordinary. So what are you doing here Cap't?
answer: Aside from having a drink with the lovely fraulein?

question: Well that pleasure requires no explanation. Chuckle...Chuckle I mean in country. Your obviously not stationed in France, or I'd know who you are.
answer: Well, there in lies the problem. We never claimed to be worth knowing. Chuckle... Chuckle.

question: All levity aside, what are you doing in France?
answer: Attending Goebbels film premiere as the frauleins escort.

question: Your the frauleins escort?
answer: Somebody has to carry the lighter. Chuckle chuckle.

question: The Captain is my date, but all three are my guests. We're old friends Major, who go back along time. Longer then a actress would care to admit. Chuckle chuckle.
answer: Well, in that case, let me raise a glass to the three luckiest men in the room.

question: I'll drink to that.
answer: I must say, that game their playing looks like a good bit of fun. I didn't join them, because your quite right Cap't, officers and enlisted men shouldn't fraternize. But seeing as we're all officers here, (Bowing to

question: okay, one game.
answer: So the object of the game, is to write the name of a famous person on your card. Real or fictitious, doesn't matter. For instance, you could write Confucius or Fu Manchu. (He SNAPS his .So let's give it a try, shall we? Everybody write your names. The Five players write their names... Then move their cards to the right... Everybody sticks their cards on their forehead...

question: I didn't think so. It's simply the young Cap't is immune to my charms. The Table's not sure what to do, is this a confrontation? Then, the Major laughs. I'm just joking, of course I'm intruding. Allow me to refill your glasses gentlemen, and I will bid you and the fraulein adieu. Eric has a bottle of thirty-three year old single malt scotch whisky from the Scottish highlands. What do you say gentlemen?
answer: Your most gracious, sir.

question: Eric, the thirty-three, and new glasses! You don't want to contaminate the thirty- three with the swill you were drinking.
answer: Five glasses.

question: Three glasses. Eric brings the three glasses, and the old bottle, pouring for the three soldiers. Major Helistrom lifts up his beer stein, and toasts;
answer: To a thousand year Reich! They all mutter, "a thousand year reich", and toast glasses. The Gestapo Major puts down his beer stein, and then WE HEAR a CLICK, under the table. Did you hear that? That's the sound of my Luger pointed right at your testicles.

question: Why do you have a Luger pointed at my testicles?
answer: Because you've just given yourself away, Cap't. Your no more German then that scotch.

question: You outside! Who are you? British, American, what? Aldo's Voice YELLS down the hole;
answer: Were American's 1 What are you?

question: I'm a German you idiot!
answer: You speak English pretty good for a German!

question: I agree! So let's talk!
answer: Okay, talk!

question: I'm a father! My baby was born today in Frankfurt! Five hours ago! His name is Max! We were in here drinking and celebrating! They're the ones that came in shooting and killing! It's not my fault!
answer: Okay, okay, it wasn't your fault! What's your name soldier?

question: Wilhelm!
answer: That's the same name as one of the guys you just killed!

question: That's the same name as one of the guys you just killed!
answer: They attacked us!

question: Okay Wilhelm... .is anybody alive on our side?
answer: No! We hear a VOICE OFF SCREEN, yell out;

question: Who's that?
answer: (To BRIDGET,

question: Wilhelm, who is that?
answer: is the girl on your side? Pause.

question: Which girl?
answer: 1 Who do you think, Von Hammersmark!

question: Yeah, she's oar's!
answer: I thought so. So you run with the American's now, huh? Now times are bad?

question: Is she okay?
answer: You despicable traitor. She's been shot, but she's alive. For now. We hear The Basterds Curse their luck Off Screen.

question: Okay Wilhelm, what'd ya say we make a deal?
answer: What's your name?

question: Aldo. Wilhelm, can I call yap Willi?
answer: Yes.

question: So Willi, you know we could lob three or four or five or six grenades down there, and your little war story ends here. But good fer you, bad fer her, you die, she dies. So what say we make a swap?
answer: Keep talking?

question: Okay, Willi here's my deal! You let me and one of my men come down to take the girl away! And we take the girl, and leave! That simple, Willi! You go your way, we go ours! And little Max, gets to grow up playing catch with his daddy! So what'ya say, Willi, we got a deal? Willi thinks... Bridget watches Willi think...
answer: Aldo?

question: I'm here Willi!
answer: I want to trust you.... But howcanI?

question: What choice ya got?
answer: I could kill the girl!

question: Well now, Willi, that's true enough. But something you need to know, so you don't get the wrong idea. Ain't none of us give a fuck bout that girl. But, admittedly, if you kill her, it would fuck up our plans. But you'll be dead by then anyway, so what'd you care? And lets not forget that little gatzenjammer Max, growin up without a pop. So in the spirit of gettin you home to him, we got a deal, Willi?
answer: Okay Aldo, I'm going to trust you! Come down, no guns! Aldo and Hirschberg come down the stairs, showing open hands. Willi keeps his machine gunn trained on them. Aldo with his hands up, says;

question: Okay Aldo, I'm going to trust you! Come down, no guns! Aldo and Hirschberg come down the stairs, showing open hands. Willi keeps his machine gunn trained on them. Aldo with his hands up, says;
answer: Hey Willi, what's with the machine gunny I thought we had a deal?

question: We do have a deal, now git the girl and go.
answer: Not so fast, Willi, we only have a deal, we trust each other. A Mexican stand off ain't trust.

question: You need guns on me for it to be a Mexican stand off.
answer: you got guns on us, you decide to shoot, we're dead. Up top, they got grenades, they drop 'em down here, your dead. That's a Mexican stand off, and that wasn't the deal.

question: Just take that fucking traitor, and go! See? Now your down here Now you get tricky - t
answer: - No tricks!- Ain't nobody gittin tricky, Willi; I swear to god, I'm too damn dumb toget tricky. But i know your scarred. I'm scarred, he's scarred, we're all scarred. So what's it gonnabe Willi? Ether we got a deal, or you might as well just shoot us now. Willi decides... He puts the machine gunn down on the bar.

question: Fine. Take that fucking traitor and get her out of my sight.
answer: Danka, Willi, danka. okay, Hirschbeg, you grab her shoulder - You fuckin bitch! I had a deal with that man! From the floor, the bloody, sweaty, and in excoriating pain , German movie star, says to the two American soldier's she's just meeting for the first time;

question: I ought'a beat your fuckin head in
answer: Stop it. Just pick her up, and get that bitch outta here.

question: Aldo, she just-
answer: - She's right.

question: What?
answer: I said, she's right. He was a Nazi soldier. If he lived, he would doomed the mission.

question: Now 'fore we yank that slug outta ya, you need to answer a few questions
answer: Few questions about what?

question: About I got three men dead back there, and why don't you try tellin us what the fuck happened?
answer: The British officer blew his German act, and a Gestapo Major saw it.

question: 'fore we get into who shot John, why did you invite my men to a rendez-vous in a basement with a bunch of Nazis?
answer: I can see, since you didn't see what happened inside, the Nazi's being there must look odd.

question: The English man, gave himself away.
answer: How did he do that?

question: He ordered three glasses. She holds up three fingers, index to pinky. We order, three glasses. She holds up three fingers, thumb to index. That's the German three. The other is odd. Germans would, and did notice it.
answer: Okay, let's pretend there were no Germans, and everything went exactly the way it was suppose to. What would of been the next step?

question: What are you thinking?
answer: I'm thinking getting a wack at plantin ole Uncle Adolph makes this a horse of a different color.

question: What's that suppose to mean?
answer: It means, your gettin us in that premiere.

question: I'm going to probably end up losing this leg, bye bye acting career, fun while it lasted. How do you expect me to walk up a red carpet?
answer: The doggie docs gonna dig that slug outta your gam. Then he's gonna wrap it up in a cast, and you gotta good how I broke my leg mountain climbing story. That's German, ain't it? Y'all like climbin mountains, don'tch?

question: With a atrocious accent, no doubt. But that doesn't exactly kill us in the crib. Germans don't have a good ear for Italian. So you mumble Italian, and brazen through it, is that the plan?
answer: That's about it.

question: That sounds good.
answer: it sounds like shit, but what else we gonna do, go home?

question: I want everybody out of this room! They start to leave. That means now, goddamnit! They RUSH OUT. He walks over to the Patient in the hospital bed, Its none other then SGT.WILLI, and yes, he's still alive. Landa pulls up a chair next to the bed, sits down. Can you speak, Sgt? Tell me everything that happened in there? The THINK BUBBLE DISSOLVES away, reveling the entrance again, and as if on perfect cue, in walks Bridget Von Hammersmark, dressed lovely, leg in a big white cast. The three basterds in their tuxedos, flank her. Fraulein Von Hammersmark, what has befallen Germany's most elegant swan?
answer: Colonel Landa, it's been years. Dashing as ever I see.

question: Flattery will get you everywhere, fraulein. They chuckle, and air kiss. So what's happened to your lovely leg, a by product of kicking ass in the German cinema, no doubt.
answer: Save your flattery, you old dog. I know too many of your former conquests, to fall into that honey pot. Chuckle-chuckle...

question: Seriously, what happened?
answer: Well, I tried my hand, foolishly I might add, at mountain climbing. And this was the result.

question: Mountain climbing? That's how you injured your leg, mountain climbing?
answer: Believe it or not, yes it is. A brief moment passes between the two...

question: Forgive me, fraulein. I don't mean laugh at your misfortune. It's just .mountain climbing? I'm curious fraulein, what could of ever compelled you to undertake such a foolhardy endeavor? The Double meaning is not lost on the German actress.
answer: Well, I chant be doing it again, I can tell you that.

question: That cast looks as fresh as my old Uncle Gustave, when were you climbing this mountain, last night?
answer: Very good eye, Colonel. It happened yesterday morning.

question: Hummm. And where exactly in Paris is this mountain? This stops her for a seconded. Then Landa laughs it off, taking them off the hook. I'm just teasing you, fraulein. You know me, I tease rough. So who are your three handsome escorts?
answer: I'm afraid neither three speak a word of German. Their friends of mine from Italy. This is a wonderful Italian stuntman, Antonio Margheriti. A very talented cameraman, Enzo Gorlomi. And Enzo's camera assistant, Dominick Decocco. The German fraulein turns to the three tuxedo wearing Basterds.

question: Italian? Really?
answer: Well, I speak alittle Italian -

question: I speak a little Tagalog, but I wouldn't begin to presume I could pass for Filipino. Don't get me wrong, I understand you were in a pickle, what with you losing your Germans. And I have nothing but admiration for improvisation. Still.... Chico Marx is more convincing. if the three of you had shown up to the premiere dressed in womans attire, it would have been more convincing. Landas eyes go to the Two Nazi Guards behind the prisoners. So your Aldo the Apache?
answer: So your The Jew Hunter?

question: Jew Hunter, , I'm a detective. A damn good detective. Finding people is my specialty. So naturally, I worked for the Nazi's finding people. And yes, some of them were Jews. But Jew Hunter? Just the name that stuck.
answer: Well you do hafts admit, it is catchy.

question: Do you control the nicknames, your enemies bestow on you? Aldo the Apache and The Little Man?
answer: What do you mean, The Little Man?

question: The Germans nickname for you.
answer: The Germans nickname for me is, The Little Man?

question: Bridget Von Hammersmark. Oh I'm sure she's in whatever, big bubbling cesspool in hell, the devil reserves for traitors of her ilk.
answer: How do you know our names?

question: Lt.Aldo, if you don't think I wouldn't interrogate every single one of your swastika marked survivors... .? We simply aren't operating on the level of mutual respect I assumed. Now, back to the whereabouts of your two Italian saboteurs. At this moment, both Hirschberg, and Donowitz, should be sitting in the very seats we left them in. Seats, 0023 and 0024, if my memory serves. Explosives, still around there ankle, still ready to explode. And your mission, some would call a terrorist plot, as of this moment, is still a go. The two Basterds don't believe this. It can't be true.
answer: That's a pretty exciting story. What's next, Eliza on the ice?

question: However, all I have to do, is pick pick up that phone right there. Inform the cinema, and your plans kupet.
answer: IF, their still there, and IF their still alive, and that's one big IF, there ain't no way, you gonna take them boys without settin off them bombs.

question: So gentlemen, lets discuss the prospect of ending the war-tonight. All three have their Chianti filled glasses. So the way I see it, since Hitlers death, or possible rescue, rests solely on my reaction...If I do nothing ...it's as if I'm causing his death, even more then yourselves. Would you agree?
answer: I guess so.

question: How about you Uitivich? Good, we more or less, all agree. Gentlemen, I have no intention, of Killing Hitler, and killing Goebbels, and Killing Gerring, and killing Boorman, not to mention winning the war single handedly for the allies, only later, to find myself standing before a Jewish tribunal. If you want to win the war, tonight, We have to make a deal.
answer: What kinda deal?

question: The kind you wouldn't have the authority to make. However, I'm sure this mission of yours, has a commanding officer? A General, I'm betting. For .. Oooh, that's a bingo. Is that the way you say it, That's a bingo?
answer: You just say, bingo.

question: What-a? Donny pantomimes again, more exaggerated, and with less patience. Affirm-ato, affirm-ato.
answer: They-o Look-o Screen-a, Not-o You-a.

question: Fantastic-o.
answer: After-teri, Set-ta, Five-o Moment-o (Pointing to

question: What-o?
answer: Confuse-i, confuss-i, confuss-i. What-a, and-o what-o, same-o?

question: Oh-o, sorr-o, I-o ment-a "What-a".
answer: After-teri, you-a set-ta boom-a, five-o moment-o, you-a, fuck-o Pphisst.

question: Affirm-ato, affirm-ato.
answer: Good-a, Luck-a.

question: Are you the manager, of this cinema? I want my money back. That actor in the movie stinks. He laughs.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: I came to visit you.
answer: Can't you see how busy I am?

question: Then allow me to lend a assist.
answer: Fredrick it's not funny, you can't be here. This is your premiere, you need to be out there with them. As Fredrick prepares to tell his little tale, with all the charm at his command, Shosanna listens, knowing the third reel is just about over, and her big reel change is coming up.

question: Normally, you would be.right. And for all the other films I do, I intend to endure evenings like tonight, in the proper sprit. However the fact remains, this film, is based on my military exploits. And in this case, my exploits consisted of me killing many men. Consequently, the part of the film that's playing now,... .I don't like watching this part.
answer: Fredrick, I am sorry, but -

question: - So, I thought, I'd come up here and do what I do best, annoy you. And from the look on your face, it would appear I haven't lost my touch.
answer: I have to get prepared for the reel change.

question: Let me do it?
answer: No.

question: Oh please, it's been two years since i've done a reel change.
answer: I said, no.

question: Come on, it's my premiere.
answer: Are you so use to the Nazi's kissing your ass, you've forgotten what the word,No" means? No Fredrick, you can't come in here, now go away! No subtitles for Fredrick needed this time, he gets it. He does a one-armed PILE DRIVE PUSH on the door, knocking both it OPEN, and Shosanna back into the room. Fredrick, a different cat then we've seen up till now, enters the booth, closing the door behind him, and LOCKING it. The quite startled Shosanna, says to Fredrick; Fredrick, you hurt me.

question: Okay Gentlemen, you can climb down. Herrman, hand them your weapon. He does. Col.Landa hands over his LUGER, and his very cool looking SS I am officially surrendering myself over to you, Lt.Raine. We are your prisoners.
answer: Thank you very much Colonel. Uitivich, cuff the Colonel's hands behind his back.

question: Is that really necessary? As Uitivich cuffs the. Colonels hands behind his back, Aldo
answer: I'm a slave to appearances. Then Aldo takes the Luger, and SHOOTS HERRMAN DEAD. The bound Col.Landa is appalled.
